This review is for the following item: HOSHANHO 8 Inch Chef Knife, 9 Layers 10CR15MOV High Carbon Steel Kitchen Knife, Japanese Professional Gyuto Chefs Knives with Octagonal Rosewood Handle. It cost $75.99 when I ordered it.This 8-inch Japanese chef‚Äôs knife has become part of my regular kitchen rotation. It replaced a western style chef knife I had been using for more than 40 years, and that says a lot. I was comfortable with my old knife, but this one is clearly an upgrade.Over time I have learned that Japanese style knives just work better for me. The blade profile sits flatter on the cutting board, so there is less rocking from tip to heel when I am prepping food. That flatter feel makes slicing and chopping feel more controlled and natural.The edge was razor sharp right out of the box and only needed a quick pass on a steel before its first use. I used it heavily for slicing, chopping, and general prep during the first week, and after that my old chef‚Äôs knife stayed in the drawer. The edge held up very well and only needed light steeling to stay sharp. After about three weeks of regular use, I touched it up on a 2000 grit ceramic whetstone and it was right back to day one sharpness.I also really like the octagonal Japanese style handle. It may not feel quite as planted as a big western handle when cutting very large or firm items, but for vegetable prep and everyday kitchen work it is noticeably more comfortable. That kind of prep probably makes up most of my time in the kitchen anyway.Visually, this knife looks great too. They feel like an artists tool. They got weight to them and a high quality feel. The steel is thicker than my last set and feels stronger. The steel goes from tip to end of handle, FULL TANG. They feel so good in the hand and just make you want to use them.I finally had a chance to use the "steak" knives on a pork dish I put together and it cut through like butter. They're all insanely sharp, so again be careful handling them. I washed all of them right out of the box and didn't realize I nearly sliced my sponge in half when I was done with them.So yeah, I'll just end that I'm more than satisfied with these. Replacing my 12 year old KitchenAid set never felt better. I did a lot of research prior to buying and it was a close call between going German or Japanese (made in Cali), then thought about Hattori Hanzo and how the Bride got her revenge. Japanese steel baby. These do not disappoint and you will not regret the purchase, I promise.EDIT - I want to touch up on folks with the rust problems and possibly put some fears to rest. These are stainless steel. Even the Cybertruck has owners complaining about rust. The best you can do to prevent it is immediately dry them as soon as you wash them and do not let them sit in water. Think about it, if you fear they're just going to rust out of nowhere, you would have potentially received one out of the box covered in rust. That's not how it works. More than likely the folks complaining about rust have either put them in a dish washer (use at your own risk) or let them sit in a pot of water or something and did not immediately dry them.My best advice using these is immediately wash and dry them off as soon as you use them.
